awd_titl_txt: CPS: Medium: Modular Power Orchestration at the Meso-scale
awd_abstract_narration:
Energy storage and power distribution play an integral part in the engineered systems that play critical roles in people's everyday lives, including transportation, utility, health, and security. In today's cyber-physical platforms, however, the generation, storage, allocation, and distribution of energy among modules is often managed in a haphazard and rigid manner that is fixed at the system design stage. The limitations of existing power management methods are clearly evident in highly-integrated meso-scale systems, which range from mobile devices to large installations such as the International Space Station. The power semantics of these meso-scale systems fall in between those of macro-scale power grids and micro-scale on-chip power management, resulting in a significant solution void. This research project aims to fill that void by establishing an agile, yet resilient, framework to design and manage power distribution and energy storage in cyber-physical systems. The broader impacts of this project will not only transform power delivery capabilities in emerging technologies such as the next generation of electric and hybrid autonomous vehicles, but also enrich inter-disciplinary education by bridging hardware-oriented power electronics design with control, system software, and application development, through curriculum integration and outreach programs.

This research will develop a principled approach towards two main goals: modularizing the management of power semantics in meso-scale cyber-physical systems, and orchestrating the power-related system-wide interactions among heterogeneous modules. We begin by introducing an innovative equivalence between the management of power distribution and the optimization of energy packet delivery. This new problem formulation allows us to re-imagine the power architecture by incorporating malleable power modules as smart energy routers, connecting and buffering bidirectional power flows between diverse functional components such as motors, processors, and sensors. This research will develop a novel approach to efficient delivery of energy packets, which will allow reasoning about optimality and trade-offs among power and performance semantics holistically. This project will also establish a new intelligent coordination framework based on formal methods, for off-line generation of on-line interfaces among power modules, aiming to orchestrate exchanges of power among modules at a full-system level, even in the face of variability and model uncertainty. This modular power flow orchestration framework is a step towards a theory of modular smart ubiquitous cyber-physical devices, empowering a paradigm shift in how next-generation systems with new semantic objectives such as long-term sustainable autonomy can be built.

por.por_cntn:
The project has worked to develop a principled approach towards two main goals: modularizing the management of power semantics in meso-scale cyber-physical systems and orchestrating the power-related system-wide interactions among heterogeneous modules. We have been especially interested in exploring a layered framework to tackle the power delivery and management challenges in cyber-physical settings where the power delivery network itself manifests as an intrinsic physical counterpart to the computing system it is supporting.
First, our research reveals the inherent and universal cyber-physical nature of modern computing systems when the full power delivery system is taken into consideration. By explicitly modeling the distribution and delivery of physical energy to individual computing units, we have been able to 1) investigate optimal design strategies for power delivery systems through the innovative method of combining voltage stacking with hybrid employment of both off-chip and on-chip charge recycling and 2) explore cross-layer power management schemes by leveraging both control theory driven microarchitecture/circuit co-design and learning assisted hierarchical dynamic voltage/frequency scaling (DVFS) framework; 3) pioneer research on comprehensively modeling the security implications of power delivery with the development of both simulation and experimentation infrastructure. Our holistic study of power delivery subsystems has yielded implementations that can not only achieve high efficiency on average and consistent reliability across various worst-case scenarios, but also accommodate system-level adaptability and dynamic allocation. These results are hugely relevant and becoming increasingly crucial as computing systems move to the age of chiplet and 3D integration. We have further demonstrated how the intrinsic properties of the power delivery network (i.e. its impedance profile) can be used as security primitives for anomaly detection and device fingerprinting and have identified novel attack vectors based on common-mode noises injected via the power charging cable. This line of research points towards considering analog properties in digital systems as security vulnerabilities. Next, recognizing that future autonomous cyber-physical systems will invariably incorporate deep learning-driven components for machine perception, which will require enormous on-board computing capability and cannot be readily satisfied by conventional general-purpose computing systems, we are interested in exploring alternative system organizations that are heterogenous with non-traditional Von Neumann architecture. Towards this goal, we have investigated 1) a modeling method to quickly and accurately estimate the performance (i.e. power/latency/area) of neural network (NN) inference accelerators and training method to obtain hardware-friendly NN models for hardware acceleration; 2) a characterization and design strategy for near-memory graph processing; and 3) novel computational sensors with embedded AI feature extraction capability. All of these techniques will help to enable next-generation computing platforms for future autonomous systems. Another consequence of the learning-driven machine perception in CPS is its effect on safety and security of the system. Our research has provided concrete examples to demonstrate direct impacts in complex CPS systems and has revealed that simple physical attacks can cause serious physical consequences (i.e. collisions) and compromise security of end-to- end trained self-driving vehicles. At the same time, the employment of heterogeneous computing systems with specialized hardware such as GPUs to execute compute-intensive operations in autonomous CPS requires that we carefully consider the scheduling, memory management, and executor models beyond the ones that have been developed for traditional homogeneous computing platforms. Therefore, in this project, we have rigorously investigated real-time scheduling strategies for CPU-GPU systems achieving fine-grain utilization of GPUs with hard timing guarantees. We have developed memory management strategies and executor models that can deliver real-time performance in ROS2 (and other middleware frameworks) when deployed using heterogeneous computing platforms. Our multi-threaded executor for ROS2 allows for custom scheduling policies beyond ROS2's default fixed priority design and is able to achieve better average and worst-case latency performance than other existing executor strategies. Our zero-copy framework for inter-component systems (such as those based on ROS2) running on heterogeneous memory is able to remove unnecessary memory operations and increase memory reuse in applications using hardware acceleration.  Finally, we have built a tremendous amount of research infrastructure to broadly benefit the larger community. Our PiCar platform is now the standard vehicle for undergraduate senior design at Washington University and we have open sourced its design to serve as an educational resource outside WashU. We have published early-stage design space exploration tools and power delivery system models including NNest, Ivory/Ivory 2.0, and PowerScout, as well as our vision-based self-driving attack code, on our group GitHub repo (https://github.com/xz-group). With respect to broader impacts, all of our research findings have been disseminated to the general public through publication of peer-reviewed papers and open source release. This award has also provided significant exposure to and professional training on topics in computer architecture, embedded/real-time systems, and power electronics to graduate students and undergraduate researchers involved. Three masters students have defended their theses and seven Ph.D. students have been partially funded for their training.
